questions.text: Which of the following cartilages form a complete ring?
questions.solution:
Cricoid cartilage forms a complete ring around the airway and this is the only laryngeal cartilage to do so.

Clinical significance:

  • Sellick's maneuver - Cricoid pressure is applied to occlude the esophagus without occluding the airway. It prevents regurgitation of gastric contents during intubation and rapid induction of anesthesia.
  • The cricoid cartilage is the narrowest part of the pediatric airway.

questions.text: An inhaled foreign body is likely to lodge in the right lung due to all of the following features except _______

choices.text: Right lung is shorter and wider than the left
Right principal bronchus is more vertical than the left bronchus
Tracheal bifurcation directs the foreign body to the right lung
Right inferior lobar bronchus is in continuation with the principal bronchus

questions.solution:
The right principal bronchus (not the right lung) is wider, shorter (2.5 cm) and more vertical than the left. The right inferior lobar bronchus is the continuation of the bronchus intermedius which is the continuation of the right principal bronchus. These differences explain why inhaled foreign bodies enter the right principal bronchus more often than the left.

The left principal bronchus is narrower, longer (5 cm) and less vertical than the right principal bronchus.

Option A says right lung and not right bronchus and hence is a wrong answer.

questions.text: Which of the following types of collagens is involved in wound healing?
questions.solution:
Type III collagen is involved in wound healing.

The tensile strength of the wound is directly proportional to the amount of collagen present, and types I and III predominate in the skin and aponeurotic layers.

Approximately 80 percent of the original strength of the tissue is obtained by six weeks after surgery. Wounds slowly continue to get stronger but may never achieve 100 percent of their previous strength.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man complains of shortness of breath and coughing at night that awakens him from sleep. He is a known case of COPD. On examination, distended neck veins and S3 sounds were noted. The bronchoalveolar lavage of this patient is given below. Identify the marked cells.
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of heart failure. The image shows heart failure cells, which are siderophages or hemosiderin-containing macrophages.

They are seen in the alveoli of patients with chronic pulmonary edema. The alveolar walls become thickened and fibrosed. These pigmented macrophages result in a brown induration of the lung.

The following image shows siderophages.

questions.text: A 70-year- old woman was diagnosed with right leg cellulitis and was admitted in hospital for 3 days. She was prescribed clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, she developed diarrhoea and abdominal pain. Her temperature was 38.8 degrees. Her blood reports revealed a Hb level of 12g/dl; WBC count of 18,000/mm3; CRP of 160mg/l. What is the most probable etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with diarrhoea following antibiotic administration is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridium difficile. 

Clostridium difficile is the most common cause of infectious diarrhoea in nosocomial infections. It is the most common antibiotic-associated diarrhoea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, which causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora, leading to the colonization of C. difficile.

Clinical features:

  • Lower abdominal pain with loose watery diarrhea.
  • Fever, leukocytosis
  • In some patients, the disease may progress to life-threatening pseudomembranous colitis.

Investigations:

  • Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool 
  • Stool culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating toxin by Hep-2 cell cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy reveals a characteristic appearance, with erythema, white plaques, or an adherent pseudomembrane.

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in the stool are used as they are both rapid and sensitive while retaining high specificity.

Oral vancomycin, metronidazole, and fidaxomicin are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

First choice treatment of C. difficile colitis:

Severity Treatment
Mild to moderate Oral Vancomycin
Severe (WBC >15,000/cu.mm, Creatinine >1.5 times baseline) Oral Vancomycin
Severe, Complicated (Shock, Ileus, Toxic Megacolon) Oral Vancomycin + IV Metronidazole ± Rectal Vancomycin
Recurrent/ multiple episodes Fecal Microbiota Transplantation (FMT)

Fidaxomicin is an alternative in all cases. Metronidazole is now reserved for non-severe infections in settings where access to first-line drugs is limited or cost is an issue. 

Recent update: Harrison's 20th edition recommends the use of vancomycin over metronidazole in the treatment of initial episodes which are mild to moderate in severity. Metronidazole is recommended only if vancomycin or fidaxomicin are not accessible. Oral metronidazole is less effective than the other options and may necessitate a longer treatment course for response.

Other options: Escherichia coli, Norovirus, Rotavirus are all causes of Traveller's diarrhea.

Other causes for Nosocomial diarrhea:

  • Clostridium perfringens,
  • Klebsiella oxytoca,
  • Staphylococcus aureus.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: A female patient on lithium tested positive for a urine pregnancy test. Lithium usage in pregnancy can lead to which of the following teratogenic effects?
questions.solution:
Lithium use in pregnancy can lead to cardiac defects. 

Ebstein's anomaly is the specific cardiac defect with lithium use in pregnancy.

In Ebstein’s anomaly, the radiological sign seen is a box-shaped heart.

questions.text: Identify this complication of burns.
questions.solution:
The image shows a 'Marjolin ulcer'.

Marjolin’s ulcer is a term used to describe a rare type of SCC (squamous cell carcinoma) which arises in sites of chronic wounds or scars.

The malignant transformation is slow, with an average latency time of approx 30 years.

The tumor may initially present as an ulceration that fails to heal; nodules may develop as the lesion progresses. Other clinical signs include rolled or everted wound margins, excessive granulation tissue, a rapid increase in size, and bleeding on touch.

questions.text: A 3rd-year MBBS student is examining a case of deviated nasal septum. Which of the following findings is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Nasal polyp will not be seen in a patient with deviated nasal septum. 

Clinical features of DNS:

  • Nasal obstruction - unilateral in C-shaped deviation and bilateral in S-shaped deviation
  • Headache - may be due to associated sinusitis or due to spur pressing on the lateral wall of the nose
  • Sinusitis - due to obstruction of ostia and poor ventilation of sinuses
  • Epistaxis - from vessels over spur or due to crusting of the nasal mucosa
  • Anosmia - especially in bilateral nasal obstruction
  • Compensatory hypertrophy of turbinates on roomier side
  • Frequent middle ear infections
  • Association with external deformities

questions.text: A worried mother brought her son for vision examination when she noticed him reading a book too closely. She says he also narrows his eyes while watching television. Examination revealed myopia. Which of the following lens should be prescribed to correct this child's vision?
questions.solution:
Concave lenses are used for correcting myopic errors.

Myopia, also known as 'short sight', is that dioptric condition of the eye in which, with the accommodation at rest, incident parallel rays come to a focus anterior to the light-sensitive layer of the retina. 

Other options:

Convex lenses are used in the correction of hypermetropic eye and presbyopic eye.

Cylindrical lenses are used in the correction of astigmatism.

questions.text: Vaccination against which of the following organisms should be administered post-splenectomy?

choices.text: Haemophilus influenzae B, Staphylococcus aureus, Influenza

questions.solution:
All post-splenectomy patients need to be vaccinated against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenza type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years).

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations must be given at least 2 weeks before the elective surgery. In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

The following vaccines are given :

  • Pneumococcal vaccine: A dose of PCV13 followed by PPSV23 ≥8 weeks later is advised. Revaccinate every five to seven years thereafter.
  • H. influenzae type b vaccine: A single dose of Hib vaccine is recommended. Revaccination is not needed for Hib.
  • Meningococcal vaccination: Two doses of the MenACWY vaccine are given ≥8 weeks apart. Revaccination is needed every five years.
  • Influenza vaccination: Vaccination against seasonal influenza should be given annually.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the capsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: A researcher wants to study the changes in the incidence of dengue fever in a particular area over the last 10 years . Which of the following is best suited for plotting this data ?
questions.solution:
Line graphs or line diagrams are the best way to plot the changes in the incidence of a disease  with passage of time in a given area.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text:
Match the objective of each phase of a clinical trial with the phase.

    Column I                                                                               

  1. Indications are finalized and guidelines formulated                
  2. Drug interactions and long-term adverse effects assessed     
  3. Efficacy and dose-ranging are determined                               
  4. Assessment of safety and tolerability

    Column II

    A. Phase I

    B. Phase II

    C. Phase III

    D. Phase IV
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1- C, 2-D, 3-B, and 4-A.

The phases of a clinical trial and their objectives are as given below.

Phase 1 (first in humans) is carried out in 10-100 participants. It aims to test the safety and tolerability of the drug. Usually, healthy volunteers are chosen. Sometimes patients with an advanced or rare disease are also considered. It generally lasts for 1-2 years.

Phase 2 (first in patients) checks the efficacy and dose-ranging of the drug. 50-500 patient subjects receive the experimental drug. It lasts for 2-3 years.

Phase 3 (multisite trial) is carried out for confirmation of the efficacy tested in phase 2. The indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. A few hundred to a few thousand patient subjects receive the drug. It lasts for around 3-5 years.

Phase 4 (postmarketing surveillance) tests for adverse effects, or those that occur only after long-term use and drug interactions. It is done in patients already on treatment with the approved drug. There is no fixed duration for this stage.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the clinic with erythematous lesions over the exposed areas of the skin like hands, arms, chest, etc. She also complains of arthralgia and breathlessness. Which among the following antibodies will be useful in diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with a photosensitive rash, arthralgias, and shortness of breath is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Anti-dsDNA antibodies are specific for the diagnosis of SLE.

SLE is an autoimmune disorder that results in damage to multiple organs and organ systems in the body most commonly seen in women of reproductive age.  

Clinical and immunological manifestations of SLE:

  1. Skin
    • acute, subacute cutaneous manifestations (photosensitivity, malar or maculopapular rash)
    • chronic cutaneous manifestations (discoid lupus, panniculitis, lichen planus-like) 
  2. Oral or nasal ulcers
  3. Non-scarring alopecia
  4. Synovitis involving ≥2 joints
  5. Serositis (pleurisy, pericarditis)
  6. Renal: 
    • Protein/Creatinine ratio >0.5
    • RBC casts
  7. Neurologic: seizures, psychosis, myelitis, neuropathy, confusional state
  8. Hemolytic anemia
  9. Leukopenia
  10. Thrombocytopenia
  11. Immunological manifestations
    • Antinuclear antibodies >reference value (positive in >98% patients)
    • Anti-dsDNA >reference value (specific)
    • Anti-Smith antibody (specific)
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (lupus anticoagulant, false-positive rapid plasma reagin)
    • Low serum complement

To diagnose SLE, at least 4 out of 11 of the above criteria must be positive. However, if a renal biopsy is suggestive of lupus nephritis and lupus autoantibodies are positive then four criteria are not required. 

Antinuclear antibody detection is sensitive for the screening of SLE but not specific to diagnose it.

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Decreases the risk of nephritis
Anti-La(SS-B) Decreases the risk of nephritis
Antineuronal  Associated with CNS lupus
Antiribosomal P Associated with psychosis or depression in CNS lupus
Anti-RNP High titers are diagnostic of mixed connective tissue disease

questions.text: ECG of a patient who presented with palpitations to the ER is shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows increased heart rate with wide QRS complexes (> 0.12s). This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). 

Types of ventricular tachycardia based on QRS morphology:

  • Monomorphic- a stable QRS morphology from beat to beat
  • Polymorphic- changing or multiform QRS variance from beat to beat. Torsades de pointes is an example of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • Bidirectional- has a beat-to-beat alternation in the QRS frontal plane axis. It is associated with digitalis toxicity or catecholaminergic polymorphic VT.

The most common cause of VT is ischemic heart disease.

Ventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses that originate within the ventricles. These impulses are conducted through the normal ventricular myocardial cells instead of the fast conducting Purkinje system. Hence, they present with wide QRS complexes ( >0.12 sec) on the ECG.

Supraventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses originating above the ventricles. These impulses reach the ventricles through the proper fast conduction pathway resulting in a narrow QRS complex. SVTs are associated with wide QRS in few exceptional conditions like:

  • Conduction block in the left or right bundle branch
  • Activation of ventricles from an accessory pathway- antidromic AVRT

The given ECG shows wide stable QRS complexes in monomorphic ventricular tachycardia:

Other options:

Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval

     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioral change, a history of multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The triad of dementia, ataxic or apractic gait and urinary incontinence is seen in normal pressure hydrocephalus.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a communicating hydrocephalus caused by delayed resorption of cerebrospinal fluid into the venous system. Dilated lateral ventricles are seen on neuroimaging and the lumbar puncture opening pressure is in the high-normal range. A history of meningeal scarring conditions such as meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage or head trauma can be obtained from some patients.

questions.text: Four patients were brought to the casualty after sustaining trauma. Which of the following is the correct match of injuries and signs among the following?

choices.text: Extra dural hemorrhage (EDH)- Pin point pupil
Penetrating injury to eustachian tube- CSF otorrhea
Penetrating injury to eye- Battle sign

questions.solution:
Gaze paresis- Mid-brain lesion, is the correctly matched pair among the given options.

Traumatic injury to the brain affecting the mid-brain or brainstem dysfunction produces:

  • Gaze paresis - Inability of the eye to look across beyond the midline.
  • Dysconjugate gaze - Inability of the eyes to work together.
  • Roving eye movements.

Battle sign and CSF rhinorrhea are features of a middle cranial fossa fracture.

Middle cranial fossa fracture is associated with:

  • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea
  • Hemotympanum
  • Ossicular disruption
  • Battle sign: Bruising behind the ear
  • 7th and 8th cranial nerve palsies

A double target sign is seen in patients with CSF rhinorrhea. The nasal discharge in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea after head trauma is mixed with blood. When this discharge is collected on a filter paper, it shows a double target sign with a central red spot and a peripheral lighter halo as seen in the image below. 

The image below shows the 'battle' sign.

Anterior cranial fossa fracture is associated with:

  • Subconjunctival hematoma
  • CSF rhinorrhea
  • Periorbital hematoma or “Raccoon eyes”

Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa (given below). 

The pinpoint pupil is seen in patients with pontine hemorrhage and opioid overdose.

questions.text: CT brain is indicated for head injury in all conditions except _____.
questions.solution:
A single episode of vomiting after head injury is not an indication for immediate CT brain. However, multiple episodes mandate a scan.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <13 at any point
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours

  • Age >65 years
  • Coagulopathy (e.g., aspirin, warfarin, or rivaroxaban use)
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: A male patient presented with swelling in his lower limb. The clinical image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis.

Lymphatic filariasis occurs due to the transmission of W.bancrofti by the bite of Culex mosquitoes. The third stage larval forms from the mosquito enter the lymphatics and lymph nodes where they develop into adult worms. The adult worms become sexually mature and mate to release microfilariae which enter the peripheral circulation.

The disease initially causes acute attacks of lymphangitis and lymphadenitis. Early treatment may even cure the disease. The lymphedema may gradually worsen and get associated with the thickening of the skin and fibrosis of lymph vessels or blockage by adult worms. Hydrocele is another common manifestation that occurs due to lymphatic obstruction.

Microfilaria can be demonstrated in blood, chylous urine, exudate of lymph varix, and hydrocele fluid, however, peripheral blood is the preferred choice. The examination of a thick and thin blood smear stained with Giemsa stain shows the microfilaria. Other methods are by examining the unstained blood under a microscope for the actively motile microfilariae and by acridine orange-microhematocrit tube technique.

The best time to collect the blood samples is at night, between 10 pm and 4 am as they are nocturnally periodic.

DEC provocation test: In this test, a small dose of DEC is given 20-50 minutes before sample collection so that the microfilaria appears in the blood even during the daytime. 

The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti.

Other Options:

  • Deep Vein Thrombosis is a condition in which a blood clot forms in a deep vein, usually in the legs. It can cause pain, swelling, and warmth in the affected area, but it doesn't lead to the type of severe swelling and disfigurement seen in the image.
  • Edems refers to the accumulation of fluid in the body's tissues, leading to swelling. While edema can cause swelling, it doesn't typically cause the extreme and localized swelling associated with lymphatic filariasis.
  • Mansonelliasis is a disease caused by another type of parasitic worm called Mansonella. It can lead to symptoms such as skin rashes, joint pain, and fever, but it doesn't typically result in the severe and localized swelling seen in the image.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presented to surgery OPD with a history of intermittent purulent discharge with a slight blood tinge from an external opening located in the perianal region. The location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this disease?

choices.text: MRI is the gold standard modality of investigation
Seton's technique induces fibrosis and  has very good evidence of healing
Sphincter division can lead on to sphincter dysfunction and incontinence
Laying open fistulotomy shows improvement but does not eradicate the disease

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of fistula-in-ano. Laying open fistulotomy is the surest management method to eradicate the disease. 

Fistula-in -ano:

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin.

The most common cause is perianal abscess. Other causes include tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Symptoms:

  • Perianal pain
  • Discharge - intermittent purulent discharge (which may be bloody) 

Goodsall's rule:

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula.

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

Exceptions to Goodsall’s Rule

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

Investigations:

The investigations available for fistula-in-ano are as follows:

  • Fistulogram
  • Endoanal ultrasound
  • MRI
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan
  • Endocoil MRI
  • Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. (Option-A)

Treatment:

  • Control of constipation
  • Sitz bath
  • Fistulotomy
  • Fistulectomy
  • Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)
  • Setons
  • Advancement flaps

Important points to remember:

Laying open is the surest method of eradication, but sphincter division may result in incontinence due to sphincter dysfunction(Option-C)

Seton's technique:

Seton’s technique is used in the management of fistula-in-ano. The seton should be non-absorbable, non-degenerative, and comfortable. A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis. It is left in place for 3 months. Seton's technique induces fibrosis and has very good evidence of healing. If there is evidence of good healing it is removed. (Option-B)

For fistulas that involve more than 30% of the sphincter or those which are distal to the dentate line, loosely placement of seton through the track helps to facilitate drainage of any sepsis and to preserve the sphincter.

This may be converted to a cutting seton by gradually tightening at regular intervals to promote fibrosis and to slowly cut through the involved sphincter muscle, thus helps in eliminating the fistula while maintaining the continuity of the sphincter.

questions.text:
A 23 yr old gravida 1, para 0 at 25 weeks gestation, presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 days. BP-104/72mm Hg, PR-72bpm.There is generalized edema. Peripheral smear shows hemolysis. Lab values are as follows:
Leukocyte count: 10,500/mm3
Platelet count: 62000/mm3
Hematocrit: 26%
AST: 90 IU/L
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is HELLP syndrome.

The typical presentation of right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, lab findings of thrombocytopenia, low hematocrit, and peripheral smear finding of hemolysis, point towards a diagnosis of  HELLP ( Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) syndrome.

Although related to preeclampsia, hypertension and proteinuria may be absent or minimal in HELLP syndrome.

Tennessee criteria used in the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome :

  • Platelet count <1 lakh,
  • AST >70 IU/L,
  • LDH >600 IU/L

Risk factors for HELLP syndrome include

  • Preeclampsia
  • abnormal placentation
  • family history of HELLP syndrome
  • elevated levels of fetal mRNA for FLT l (vascular endothelial growth factor rfi­ receptor 1) and
  • Multiparity
  • Maternal age >34 years
  • European descent
  • History of previous poor pregnancy outcomes

Laboratory evaluation in HELLP:

  • Complete blood cell (CBC) count: Thrombocytopenia, anemia with possible reticulocytosis
  • Coagulation studies: Normal prothrombin time, 50% may have prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time
  • Peripheral smear: Schistocytes, helmet cells, and burr cells secondary to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Serum aspartate aminotransferase/alanine aminotransferase (AST/ALT) levels: Elevated secondary to liver dysfunction
  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level: Elevated secondary to liver dysfunction or hemolysis
  • Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN)/creatinine with acute renal failure
  • Bilirubin level: Increased secondary to hemolysis
  • Haptoglobin level: Decreased secondary to hemolysis
  • Fibrinogen levels: Low secondary to increased coagulation
  • D-dimer: Increased due to fibrinolysis/DIC

HELLP syndrome may lead to the development of DIC which manifests as increased fibrin split products and decreased fibrinogen levels.

Other options:

Disorder

 AST (SGOT) U/L Bilirubin (mg/dL)
Cholestasis of pregnancy Up to 200 1–5
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy 200–800 4–10
Hepatitis 2000+ 5–20

questions.text: An incidental ovarian mass is found when evaluating a 19-year-old girl for kidney stones. The mass is removed and its contents are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient with an asymptomatic ovarian mass consisting hair, bone, and sebaceous material is a mature teratoma. 

Teratomas are germ cell tumors. They contain embryonic tissues leading to the differentiation of cells along these pathways. There are three classes of teratomas:

  • Mature (benign) teratomas (eg: Dermoid cyst)
  • Immature (essentially malignant) teratomas (eg: solid teratoma)
  • Monodermal (highly specialized) tumors (eg: Struma ovarii)

Mature cystic teratoma, also known as dermoid cysts are unilocular in structure and have a smooth surface. They usually are lined by squamous epithelium with hair follicles leading to the formation of sebaceous material and hair. Other structures like teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and mucous membranes can also be found. 

Most patients are asymptomatic. Some patients may have symptoms because of the mass size of the teratoma. In other patients, ovarian teratomas can result in torsion of the ovary. Other rare complications include rupture of the cyst and spillage of contents into the abdominal cavity. 

Treatment of mature teratomas involves excision in order to prevent complications. Otherwise, mature teratomas are generally innocent. 

Other options: 

Option A - Immature teratomas such as solid teratomas of the ovary are solid and trabeculated. They also contain cartilage, bone, hair, and sebaceous material. There is no structural order. They are generally malignant. Grossly, they have a smooth external surface and are solid on sectioning. There may be areas of necrosis or hemorrhage. 

The following image shows both mature (left) and immature teratomas (right). 

Option C - Struma ovarii is a type of highly specialized teratoma that contains only thyroid tissue. If it is functioning, it may lead to hyperthyroidism. 

Option D - Granulosa cell tumors arise from the sex cords of the gonads. They are solid and generally produce estrogen. They can cause precocious puberty in children, hyperestrogenism in adults, and post-menopausal bleeding. They vary in appearance and range from microscopic to large, solid and cystic, encapsulated masses. If hormonally active, they may be yellow due to intracellular lipids.

questions.text: Which of the following peaks marked in the image below is responsible for ovulation ?
questions.solution:
The label marked 2 represents the LH surge ,which is responsible for ovulation.

Phases of the menstrual cycle :

Follicular phase (days 0–14)

  • A primordial follicle develops to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles.
  • LH and FSH receptors are up-regulated in theca and granulosa cells.
  • Estradiol levels increase and cause proliferation of the uterus.
  • FSH and LH levels are suppressed by the negative feedback effect of estradiol on the anterior pituitary.
  • Progesterone levels are low.

Ovulation (day 14)

  • Occurs 14 days before menses, regardless of cycle length. Thus, in a 28-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 14; in a 35-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 22.
  • A burst of estradiol synthesis at the end of the follicular phase has a positive feedback effect on the secretion of FSH and LH (LH surge).
  • Ovulation occurs as a result of the estrogen-induced LH surge.
  • Estrogen levels decrease just after ovulation (but rise again during the luteal phase).
  • Cervical mucus increases in quantity; it becomes less viscous and more penetrable by sperm.

Luteal phase (days 14–28)

  • Progesterone levels are high.
  • The corpus luteum begins to develop, and it synthesizes estrogen and progesterone. Vascularity and secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for receipt of a fertilized egg.
  • Basal body temperature increases because of the effect of progesterone on the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As a result, estradiol and progesterone levels decrease abruptly.

Menses (days 0–4)

  • The endometrium is sloughed because of the abrupt withdrawal of estradiol and progesterone.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most radiosensitive tumour?
questions.solution:
The radiosensitive tumor among the following is Ewing's sarcoma. All others are radioresistant tumors.

Ewing sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor characterized by primitive round cells without obvious differentiation. It accounts for 6% to 10% of primary malignant bone tumors.

Ewing sarcoma follows osteosarcoma as the second most common group of bone sarcomas in children. Approximately 80% of affected patients are younger than 20 years. Boys are affected slightly more frequently than girls. Usually, the tumor arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis. Fever, elevated sedimentation rate, anemia, and leukocytosis may be seen.

Plain radiographs show a destructive lytic tumor with permeative margins that extend into the surrounding soft tissues. The characteristic periosteal reaction produces layers of reactive bone deposited in an onion-skin fashion.

Ewing's sarcoma is managed with a combination of radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and surgery. This sarcoma is highly sensitive to radiotherapy and in certain cases, tumors affecting important bones can be treated with radiotherapy or a combination of radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: Which among the following dementia presents with capgras syndrome?
questions.solution:
Capgras syndrome is a rare delusion of misidentification where the patient believes that someone close to him has been replaced by an imposter who looks exactly the same. Capgras syndrome along with other visual hallucinations are seen in Lewy body dementia or DLW ( Dementia with lew body). Other symptoms include depression, sleep disorders and delusions

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A young male patient was brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed at a railway station. As there was no pulse felt, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed ventricular fibrillation. Immediate defibrillation was performed. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Chest compressions should be resumed immediately following shock delivery.

Pulse check and reanalysis of the cardiac rhythm is performed only after 2 minutes of chest compression and rescue breaths.

This is because the heart is temporarily stunned by a defibrillator shock and so chest compressions would benefit by providing coronary blood flow during this period.

questions.text: A baby presents to the OPD and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a capillary hemangioma involving the left upper lid and periocular area. A capillary haemangioma is the most common tumor of the orbit and periorbital area in childhood.

Hemangioma is a benign tumor caused by the abnormal growth of blood vessels. Types of hemangioma are:

  1. Capillary hemangioma (most common)
  2. Juvenile/ strawberry hemangioma
  3. Cavernous hemangioma
  4. Pyogenic hemangioma

Capillary hemangioma may present as small isolated lesions or large masses that can cause visual impairment (due to mechanical ptosis and the resulting sensory deprivation amblyopia), systemic effects (severe thrombocytopenia), or exist as part of PHACE syndrome (Posterior fossa anomalies, Hemangioma, Arterial lesions, Cardiac abnormalities, Eye or Endocrine abnormalities)

30% of lesions resolve by the age of 3 years and about 75% by the age of 7. On histology, they show thin-walled capillaries with scant stroma as shown below.

Indications for treatment are:

  1. Visual (amblyopia, astigmatism, occlusion, strabismus)
  2. Cosmesis
  3. Optic nerve compression
  4. Exposure keratopathy

Capillary hemangioma regresses spontaneously very often. Treatment options include:

  • Beta-blockers- oral propranolol, topical timolol.
  • Steroids- intralesional triamcinolone or betamethasone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids.
  • Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine- for steroid-resistant sight-threatening lesions
  • Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser.

Option A: Port wine stain is a congenital low-flow vascular malformation that may occur anywhere in the body and does not fade away with time. Visually they appear as partially or completely blanchable, pink to red or reddish brown patches, mostly on the head and neck. This lesion is associated with syndromes such as Sturge-Weber syndrome and occult spinal dysraphism.

Option B: Cavernous hemangiomas are large, cavernous blood-filled vascular spaces separated by connective tissue stroma. They are infiltrative and involve deep structures. They do not regress spontaneously. Von Hippel–Lindau disease is associated with cavernous hemangiomas. These vascular lesions are commonly found in the cerebellum, brain stem, retina, pancreas, and liver.

Option C: Salmon patches or naevus simplex (as shown below) are small, ill-defined, pink-colored macules commonly seen over the glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia. It is a common vascular birthmark and disappears within 1 year.

questions.text: A newborn presents with jaundice for 15 days. He has clay-colored stools and hepatomegaly. Ultrasound is performed and shown below. What is the name of the ultrasound finding?
questions.solution:
The newborn with persistent jaundice for more than 14 days, clay-coloured stool, and hepatomegaly is likely to have biliary atresia. The ultrasound confirms the diagnosis by demonstrating the triangular cord sign. 

The triangular cord sign represents the cone-shaped fibrotic mass cranial to the bifurcation of the portal vein. This density is echogenic and represents the fibrous remains of the porta hepatis. A ≥ 4 mm thickness of the echogenic anterior wall of the right portal vein (EARPV) measured on a longitudinal ultrasound scan, strongly suggests biliary atresia.

Biliary atresia is a rare, life-threatening condition in newborns where the bile ducts inside or outside the liver are blocked or absent, preventing bile flow from the liver to the intestine. This leads to bile buildup, liver damage, and eventually cirrhosis if untreated. The exact cause is unknown, but it may involve genetic and environmental factors. Symptoms include jaundice, pale stools, dark urine, and an enlarged liver. Diagnosis involves blood tests, imaging, and sometimes a liver biopsy. The primary treatment is the Kasai procedure, which can restore bile flow, but many children eventually require a liver transplant.

Other options: 

Option A: The falciform ligament sign is seen in the case of pneumoperitoneum. Here, the air outlines the appearance of the falciform ligament as seen in the X-ray below. 

Option C: Double bubble sign occurs due to dilated stomach and duodenum in duodenal atresia. It is seen in X-rays and ultrasound. The following image depicts the double bubble sign. 

Option D: Target sign is seen in infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. This is due to hypertrophied hypoechoic muscle surrounding echogenic mucosa. The following ultrasound image shows target sign.
